The convolution of two even functions is also even.

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: âˆ€ (n : â„•), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "âˆ€ n âˆˆ â„•, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

type: âˆ€ (n : â„•), Even (n * (n - 1))

docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

type: âˆ€ (n : â„•), Even n âˆ¨ Odd n
name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, the sum `m + n` is even if and only if `m` and `n` are both even or both odd. In other words, the parity of the sum of two natural numbers is the same as the parity of the individual numbers. Here, `Even` is a property of a number that is defined to be true if the number can be expressed as the sum of two equal numbers.

type: âˆ€ {m n : â„•}, Even (m + n) â†” (Even m â†” Even n)
name: Nat.even_add
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, the sum `m + n` is even if and only if `m` and `n` are both even or both odd. In other words, the parity of the sum of two natural numbers is the same as the parity of the individual numbers. Here, `Even` is a property of a number that is defined to be true if the number can be expressed as the sum of two equal numbers.
